<Link id="l01246" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1246"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42;</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01255" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1255"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42;     sequence types:</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01257" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1257"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42;       pointer type</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01810" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1810"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; @&#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01811" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1811"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42;/</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01813" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1813"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/&#42;&#42;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01814" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1814"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; @defgroup LLVMCCoreValues Values</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01815" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1815"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01816" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1816"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; The bulk of LLVM&#39;s object model consists of values, which comprise a very</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01817" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1817"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; rich type hierarchy.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01818" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1818"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01819" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1819"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; LLVMValueRef essentially represents llvm::Value. There is a rich</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01820" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1820"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; hierarchy of classes within this type. Depending on the instance</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01821" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1821"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; obtained, not all APIs are available.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01822" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1822"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01823" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1823"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; Callers can determine the type of an LLVMValueRef by calling the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01824" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1824"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; LLVMIsA&#42; family of functions (e.g. LLVMIsAArgument()). These</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01825" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1825"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; functions are defined by a macro, so it isn&#39;t obvious which are</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01826" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1826"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; available by looking at the Doxygen source code. Instead, look at the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01827" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1827"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; source definition of LLVM&#95;FOR&#95;EACH&#95;VALUE&#95;SUBCLASS and note the list</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01828" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1828"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; of value names given. These value names also correspond to classes in</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01829" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1829"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; the llvm::Value hierarchy.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01830" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1830"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01831" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1831"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; @&#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01832" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1832"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42;/</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01834" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1834"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Currently, clang-format tries to format the LLVM&#95;FOR&#95;EACH&#95;VALUE&#95;SUBCLASS</span></CodeLine>
